title: 110_s2812
content: The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the Act, increases the types of originating sites and expands the practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. It also improves the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Act expands the types of originating sites for telehealth services to include skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, community mental health centers, qualified community programs, county mental health clinics, and any other site with a telecommunications system. The Act expands originating sites for telehealth services to include various facilities. Amendments to the Social Security Act state that no facility fee shall be paid to certain originating sites. The amendments made by this section will apply to services provided 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services includes an amendment to the Social Security Act to broaden the definition of a practitioner to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, and qualified speech-language pathologists. The amendment broadens the definition of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services to include pathologists, audiologists, certified providers, and other individuals or entities deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The effective date for these amendments is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment broadens the definition of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services to include pathologists, audiologists, certified providers, and other individuals or entities deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The effective date for these amendments is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. IMPROVEMENT OF PROCESS FOR UPDATING THE LIST OF TELEHEALTH SERVICES. The Telehealth Advisory Committee will provide recommendations to the Secretary regarding the addition or deletion of services and HCPCS codes for telehealth. If a recommendation is not implemented, the Secretary must publish a statement in the Federal Register explaining the decision. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to establish the Telehealth Advisory Committee within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, consists of 7 members including practicing physicians and non-physician healthcare providers. They make recommendations on services and HCPCS codes for telehealth payment authorization. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, consists of 7 members including practicing physicians and non-physician healthcare providers. Requirements for appointing members include prior experience with telemedicine or telehealth, preference for those currently providing services, a balance of specialties and regions, and consideration of expertise. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, consists of 7 members including practicing physicians and non-physician healthcare providers. Members serve terms specified by the Secretary, meet twice a year, and have no permanent status under the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary can establish the committee despite any limitations on advisory committees. Stakeholder recommendations are considered.
